elements.text: [Part One]
Banging on door.
[OC]: Let me in! You have to help me. Please!
All right, all right.
[OC]: Hurry!
Door opens.
What's so urgent? Oh. Sabian!
This is Nyssa, my companion. She collapsed. Her temperature has fallen dramatically and it's still falling. I didn't know where else I could go.
That's all right, you're here now. Help me get her inside. Sabian!
I'm here. Do you need help carrying her, sir?
It's all right, I can manage. Do you know what's wrong?
Not yet, no. Put her down there.
Here?
I brought your bag.
Good, good. This is my assistant, Sabian.
And you are?
I'm the Doctor. Yes, I appreciate the irony. I'll answer all your questions, but Nyssa
Has this happened before?
Twice. Several weeks ago now. I induced deep sleep for forty eight hours and I thought I'd cured her, but
You induced deep sleep? How?
With a delta-wave augmenter. How else? Look, this may be important. She seemed fine after that, but recently she's shown evidence of psychic sensitivity that has left her weak.
She's been off-world?
Yes, that's right.
I see.
She's going to be all right?
She's in a critical condition.
The next hour will be crucial. You should wait outside.
Birds singing. Door opens, footsteps.
How is she?
She's stabilised. She is still seriously ill. You brought her here just in time. We weren't properly introduced. I'm Shayla, although I think you already know that.
I know you by reputation. I'm sorry to have imposed myself on you. Is Nyssa awake? Can I talk to her?
No, not yet. While we wait for her to recover, perhaps you could answer a few questions.
Ah. I am the Doctor, a traveller.
But you're not Nyssa's father.
Her father died. I pledged to look after her what seems like a lifetime ago now.
I see.
We travel together. Well, you know what they say. It broadens the mind.
You have exposed her to danger, to evil.
Despite my good intentions.
Well, you know what they say about good intentions.
Now look here. If Nyssa could, she'd tell you that she travels with me through choice.
You've been awake all night, haven't you? You haven't eaten. Perhaps we could discuss this over breakfast?
First I want to see Nyssa.
As you wish.
Regular noise like a large clock ticking.
Father?
Noise stops.
Nyssa, Nyssa, it's me. It's the Doctor. You collapsed again. I brought you here in the Tardis.
I don't remember that. Where are we?
Where do you think we are?
That bird. It's a crested Avar. I think it's Traken. We're on Traken.
Yes, that's right. Here, look. I brought your old clothes from the Tardis. They'll help you blend in.
But Traken was destroyed.
Yes, but it hasn't been yet. Not for about three thousand years. It's probably best not to mention that to anyone, all the same.
Three thousand years?
About that. I'm getting better at steering the Tardis, don't you think?
But
It's time travel, Nyssa. If Tegan could cope with seeing her planet's past and future, I'm sure someone with your scientific training can.
Why did you bring me here?
Where else could I find an expert on Trakenite biology? Shayla's one of the best.
What have you told her?
That we're travellers. I kept it as vague as I can. You should do the same.
Door opens.
Ah. This is Shayla's assistant. Er, Sabian, wasn't it?
Door closes.
That's right.
Sabian, you saved my life. Thank you.
Shayla saved your life, Lady Nyssa. Doctor, I think Nyssa needs to rest. And Shayla asked you to join her. She's obliged to report your presence to the Consulate.
Yes, of course. Are you going to be all right?
I think so.
I could stay with you, if you want company?
Yes. Yes, I'd like that.
Splendid. I'll pop in later to see how you're getting on.
Footsteps, door opens.
Consul Hyrca. (pronounced Her-sha.)
Consul Janneus, it is barely dawn. Why have you summoned me here?
There was an arrival. Physician Shayla reports that a man brought a young woman to her during the night for medical treatment.
From outside the Union?
There is some confusion. The woman is a daughter of Traken. It is unclear who the man is. One of us must commune with the Source, and the other must stand watch.
I shall stand watch.
Agreed.
Footsteps.
I am ready. O Source that shines on all Traken, grant me, Janneus, loyal Consul of all the worlds of the Union, the illumination of thy perfect light.
Door slides open.
Foster, I have an appointment with the Consuls.
You must wait to enter, Lady Shayla. The Consuls are in communion with the Source.
We understand, Etrayk.
Will they be long?
The Source will take as long as it needs to, sir.
Perhaps we should get back to Nyssa in the meantime. If her condition's as serious as you say, then every minute treating her could be critical.
Sabian will keep her condition stable. We will wait here.
Janneus?
I have seen much. There is danger, and a pattern that not even the Source can fully define. One that stretches across Space and Time.
What course of action does the Source advise?
It was reluctant to say.
Reluctant?
That's the best word for it. Consul Hyrca, I am convinced the Source is withholding information from us.
But that's
Yes, Consul, I know it's impossible. (sighs) We must meet these off-worlders and use our own judgement. Has Shayla brought them here?
The man is outside. I shall summon him.
Door slides open.
Through here, please.
Good morning, Consuls of Traken.
Door slides closed.
Consuls, this is the Doctor. These are Consuls Janneus and Hyrca.
Good morning.
Hello, Doctor.
Two Consuls. I'll have to be on my best behaviour.
There are times when you are not?

It's a figure of speech. I really must stop using them. You'll have to forgive me, I always find it difficult to relax somewhere so tranquil. In my experience, every paradise has its serpent somewhere.
Is your conscience really so troubled?
Shayla, what is the condition of the Doctor's travelling companion?
I've just been in to see Nyssa. She's a lot better, and
She's critically ill.
Will she survive?
The darkness is upon her. I can't be sure that the light of the Source has reached her in time.
I'm sorry, what exactly do you think is wrong with her?
Exposure to evil, even the smallest amount, can corrode the soul. And that is what has happened to Nyssa.
You make it sound like radiation, like a cancer.
That is precisely the effect it has. The Source protects us, protects all in the Union, from evil's influence. But away from the light of the Source, the malign take hold. You're laughing, Doctor.
It doesn't work like that.
You don't think there is evil in this universe?

Oh, I've travelled quite widely and met the most terrible people with the most appalling beliefs. I consider them evil, but I'm sure if you were to ask them, they'd tell you that I'm the monster, not them. Evil is relative.
And this is what all outsiders think, is it?
No, simply my opinion. I ought to warn you that I don't hold a Doctorate in Theology. At least, I don't think so. I may have picked up an honorary one somewhere or other. I lose track.
Your philosophy is flawed.
It is?
After all, Traken exists in the state of perfection.
Ah.
You don't think that Traken is perfect?
The Union of Traken is one of the most beautiful and peaceful places I have ever visited. But perfection is something we should strive for, not something we can ever attain.
And what faults do you find here, sir?
Well, Traken has the death penalty, doesn't it? In extreme cases, you execute criminals.
To prevent the spread of evil. To protect all we hold dear. To maintain perfection.
And your leaders are picked from within the elite, by members of the elite.
I understand that upon some planets you become the ruler by killing your opponents.
Here the Source guides us. The Source is perpetual, infallible.
We bathe in its light, while the lesser races must skulk in the shadows.
I was forgetting another figure of speech
Yes?
Never discuss religion or politics at the dining table.
No wonder you are jealous of us, Doctor. We have the incorruptible light of the Source. Other races have false gods, or worse, they have no gods at all. The whole universe envies us.
(a young woman) Our course is steady, sir. All ship's systems fully operational and at maximum capacity.
NARTHEx: As they have been every day for two and a half millennia.
Vigilance is our sacred duty, Captain.
NARTHExX: You're new, aren't you, Anona?
That's right, sir. I was recruited on
NARTHExX: I know who you are. I do check the backgrounds of my crew.
Sir, I meant no disrespect.
Signal.
Ah.
Kwundaar summons you, sir.
Yes.
It must be a supreme honour to stand face to face with the greatest leader. NARTHExX: There was a time when I thought like that.
You mean to test my faith, of course, sir.
NARTHExX: Yes. Yes, of course I do. Well, Anona, you may take your reward.
Sir?
NARTHEx: I'll allow you to go in my place, this once.
(delighted) Sir!
Footsteps.
Hello?
Door opens.
Is anyone there?
Distant evil-sounding laugh.
Hello again, Nyssa. You're looking better.
Sabian has given me something for the headache. I feel so weak.
Well, we're all doing our best. Quick, before the others come back, what can you tell me about the history of Traken at this time?
My people didn't study our past. After all, what could it teach us?
It would come in rather useful now, don't you think?
All I Know is that you've brought us to the Primeval times, before the time of the Keepers, when the Source governed itself.
Have you ever heard of Shayla?
No.
The book I found in the Tardis library said she was the greatest authority Traken medicine ever knew.
By my time, all illness and disease had been eradicated. We had no need for medicine. Are you worried about her?
Well, she seems to think you're possessed by evil spirits.
That's nonsense. One thing I do remember, people in the past were more superstitious. There was religion, so Traken wasn't a true paradise.
All credit to her, you're responding to the treatment she's using. Although whatever it is that's wrong, I doubt it's the devil's work.
I can't see.
Follow my voice. Follow.
The voice sounds like it is coming from underwater, distorted. Door opens, noise.
My lord?
Door closes. Silence.
Look at me.
I'm sorry, I
Speak to me. I can feel it. The Source, it burns.
If we're too close to the Union, we could move the ship away. We could
No, no, no. I want it to burn. I'll not hide from it. You, you're not Captain Narthex.
No, sir. I am Lieutenant Anona. I recently graduated
I know you. You have the reputation of being particularly devout.
You're in my mind.
Ah, you feel me there?
Yes.
Yet you don't resist.
It is not my place to.
Good. What were you before you joined my struggle?
I worked ah!
No! That was not before. You may remember a time before you were here. That time did not exist. It's a dream, elaboration.
You are right, sir. Forgive me.
You would not want to see my face.
Sir, I am at your mercy. I will obey you without thought.

(laughs) Yet as you mouth these words you still question me with your thoughts. That's my curse. I know that every follower has them. I know that every mind is devious, and every being that ever lived is a liar, a hypocrite, a cheat. I was betrayed, questioned.
Sir, I will obey you. Whatever I might think, I will not speak treason, and wherever you lead, I will follow. I will not betray you.
Yes, that is all I can ask of you. You're a good servant.
I believe in you, sir, but I don't understand why you are here, on the edge of the Union of Traken. Any closer to the Source and it will destroy you. You aren't trapped here, so
No, it is they who are trapped. The people of Traken, prisoners in their walled paradise.
Yet, yet they are content to stay where they are. And you can never hope to destroy the Source. It's impossible.

I have provided for this moment. Reached through Time and Space, found a vulnerable soul, exploited their weakness, and at my command, my agent will soon bring the walls of paradise down. Return to your duties. Prepare for that moment.
Sir.
Door opens.
Sabian, I'm looking for Shayla. Do you have any idea where she is?
Door closes.
Er, no, sorry, I don't.
I see. You might be able to help. Could you tell me about the treatment Shayla's giving Nyssa? Whatever it is, it's helping.
A simple remedy for the fever. Beyond that, we are merely letting the Source do its work.
The Source. Ah, yes. It's where you get all your energy from.
It is more than that. It is a sentient sun. The Source shines down on Traken and its people, while the rest of the universe has to live in the shadows.
But you know it's a machine?
Of course. We built it, after all. Or our ancestors did.
You don't worship it.
(laughs) Traken is a world of science, Doctor. We admire the Source for what it is, a perfect piece of engineering.
But you don't ask the Source to provide for you.
Pray to it to grant wishes? No, Doctor. After all, what could we wish for that we don't already have here in abundance.
Consuls, you sent for me.
Shayla, the Doctor does not know you are here?
I've instructed Sabian to keep him occupied.
You see, the off-worlder's presence alone is enough to make people break their word, to disrupt our way of life. I fear where this is leading.
You would blame the Doctor for our hypocrisy?
Show respect, Shayla.
You heard him say it yourself. The Doctor sees himself as a serpent in our paradise. He questions our authority. He questions the Source itself.
What is your patient's condition?
Nyssa shows little improvement. She's been exposed to terrible evils. She is suppressing anger, she has known fear. Her mental defences and barriers are almost non-existent.
Can you cure her?
No. Given time, the Source may be able to.
Time? How much time?
Years, certainly. And I'm not sure she has the strength for more than a few days.
Such evil inflicted on an innocent.

I've talked to the girl. She's reluctant to give too many details, but she saw her father murdered, she's encountered soulless creatures, machine men and other abominations created to destroy all other forms of life.
The Doctor is completely irresponsible.
It is deeper than that, Hyrca. His actions border on the abusive. It is a wonder Nyssa has not been murdered these monsters.
From what I gather, one of the Doctor's travelling companions was killed in the course of their travels. Nyssa is convinced that the Doctor is a good man.
Ha! He's clearly conditioned her.
I think he's a good man, Consul Hyrca.
On what evidence?
He may very well be a good man compared with other outsiders, but that is not the standard by which we judge people, Shayla.
We should prosecute this Doctor, impound his travel machine.
That is what the Source has ruled?
The Source remains silent on this matter. My opinion is we ask the Doctor to leave the Union.

Nevertheless, we agree it is clear that the Doctor is dangerous. We must take every measure to prevent his malevolent influence spreading. If the Doctor leaves, and leaves swiftly, then I agree that may be for the best.
And Nyssa? Without the Source and the medical resources here, she will die.
Someone somewhere else will have the knowledge to save her.
No, Consul, I don't think they will.
Our concern is for the entire Union. If Nyssa must die to preserve what we have, then so be it.
Welcome back, Anona. So, was it the greatest honour of life?
I'm sorry?
Meeting our leader, the living god.
He seemed sad.

NARTHExX: Huh. Imagine being able to read minds. It's bad enough me knowing what I'm thinking half the time. I can't imagine what it would be like hearing other people's thoughts too. Did you try to see his face?
He told me not to look.
NARTHExX: But you aren't trying to picture it? You're not curious?
Not about that.
NARTHExX: You want to know why he's skulking here, when he could conquer the galaxy.
You can
Read your mind? (laughs) No, I can't, Lieutenant. We've all thought it. People are often drawn to what they can't have. Moths to flames, men to other men's wives.
He's envious of us?
NARTHExX: He can have everything he wants except the Source, and that is why he wants it. That's my theory, anyway. No one knows what he wants, or where he's from. No one's ever dared ask.
He told me that we should prepare. That he would soon control the Source.

How? The Source senses us. Just a little nearer and it will incinerate us, or turn us into statues. Oh yes, it sounds like a fairy story, but there's a fair few who've tried. If we cross that line, Lieutenant, we'll find out why none of them have ever come back.
The Greatest Leader said he had an agent on Traken.
NARTHExX: Then the Source already knows, and the Consuls will be moving in for the kill.
Birds singing. Footsteps.
Doctor?
Ah, Shayla. I was wondering where you were.
I met with the Consuls.
And were Nyssa and I on the agenda?
Yes.
What was decided?
I disagreed with them, Doctor.
Ah. Bad news.
The Consuls wish you to leave Traken. They feel you are a bad influence. You have until nightfall to leave, and you must pledge never to return to the Union.
I see. And Nyssa?
You must take her with you.
Without treatment, she will die, and you're the only person who can save her life.
Yes, I told them.
So they're condemning an innocent girl to death.
I disagreed with them, but they were unanimous. Evil must not be allowed to spread her.
Nyssa is not evil. I am not evil. Shayla, things are not as simple as Traken philosophy seems to allow for. Wait, you said the Consuls are unanimous. I thought they relied on the Source for advice.
The Source hasn't ruled on this matter.
Why?
They don't know. Doctor, the matter is settled.
It most certainly isn't.
Shayla, come quickly. Nyssa is in relapse.
Nyssa groaning. Door opens. Footsteps.
Nyssa.
Nyssa groans.
Please, stay out of the way, Doctor.
Of course.
Her temperature has fallen again.
It's as though she's in shock. Nyssa, can you hear me?
Nyssa moans.
Breathe deep. Relax. Can you flex your legs? Loosen her collar, Sabian.
Did you hear that?
She's stabilising. Yes, I think she's sleeping normally
Her condition has regressed. Keep watch, Sabian. Doctor
If you force me to take her away from here, she'll die.
The decision has been made. The Source is infallible.
But the Source didn't make the decision, remember?
Yes, that might be it. We could lodge an appeal, insist we wait for the Source to speak on the matter. It would delay things for another day, at least.
We need more than a day.
Doctor, if we don't find a cure, then I don't think Nyssa will survive that long.
Don't say that.
I'm sorry, Doctor, it's true. I thought that I could keep her stable. I can't. I don't even know the nature of the illness, let alone its cure.
Then why lodge the appeal?
There might be another way. Kwundaar.
Consul, no!
What is that, a drug?
His followers are fanatics! Murderers and degenerates.
Not a local, then.
No. He lives in the stars beyond the Union. But his followers worship him and say he's omniscient, that he grants them all that they desire.
Sounds like a man to have in your corner.
He destroys all those who don't follow him. He stands for everything we on Traken abhor. He might satisfy the base desires of primitives, but
But he's our only hope, so tell me where to find him and I'll take the Tardis and
No, that's too obvious. The Consuls want you to leave, but Kwundaar is the greatest threat to our way of life. The Consuls will destroy your Tardis rather than let you have any contact with him.
They should make up their minds.
There is a way for you to go to him. Come with me. Sabian, if I'm missed, you are to say I have taken the Doctor to the northern shores for the day.
My lady, please don't do this.
Traken has a spaceport?
A small one. We still need to trade a few items with the rest of the universe.
I didn't think we outsiders met your standards.
Some are close enough for us to turn a blind eye, but they show their true colours if you show them enough money.
A ship is landing.
Excuse me! Is this pad three? Do you know Captain Kabe? (pronounced Car-bay.)
I am he, madam. What can I do for you?
I need passage out of the Union.
We both do.
I thought I was going alone?
We need passage. I can pay.
Ah.
Smuggle you out of the Union? Huh, that's a new one. It's usually the other way round.
We have business to attend to outside. We're planning to return.
Are you now? And can I ask what this business is?
No, you may not. Captain, I am a senior physician, and if I recommend that your permit to operate within the Union should be revoked on quarantine grounds
Then I'll take you to the courts, my lady. You think getting this permit was easy? I've passed all your checks.
Captain, a friend of mine is going to die unless I get help. We'll have to leave immediately. Please name your price.
Not a terribly good bargaining strategy, sir, but, er, I'll take your money.
Have you been Shayla's assistant for long?

For two years. She's a genius, Nyssa. The finest physician Traken has ever known. The first week I was here, she saved the life of a man found drifting in space after an accident. He had been pronounced dead, but she saved him. And you are far from dead, so she will save you.
I feel weak.
Don't worry. The Source will sustain you.
I want the Doctor here. Where is he?
I don't know. He and Shayla left together a few hours ago.
Left? To go where?
The northern shores?
Sabian.
They've gone to the northern shores.
Door opens.
Consul Hyrca. This is a medical ward and
Door closes.
You are Nyssa.
Yes.
I, I see. Well, fetch me Shayla, please.
She isn't here. The northern shores.
Pardon?
She and the Doctor have gone to the northern shores.
She lodged an injunction against the Consulate with the courts. I want to know what she's playing at. Nyssa, you are ordered to attend a meeting with the Consuls immediately.
She's too weak to
Immediately!
Sir, there's a merchant ship leaving the Union. It will cross the boundary in this sector.
NARTHEx: It's not a scheduled flight?
No. And it's not on a standard route.
Kwundaar knows about this.
It must be that agent he was talking about. Ah! Yes, I understand.
NARTHExX: He's talking to you?
Yes. We are to intercept the ship, bring the passengers to him unharmed. Do what we will with the ship and any of its crew.
There should be rich pickings. Battlestations, everyone. Do you want this kill, Lieutenant?
Yes, sir.
Then suit up and get over to the launch bays.
So, business is good, and as long as I keep me nose clean
And what do you know about Kwundaar?
Huh. His followers are incredibly loyal. Runs his operation like a religion. But the way he acts, he's more like a pirate if you ask me. His people do all right out of it. Share the
plunder.
The wages of sin.
Oh, it's a good salary, my lady, and the way they see it, if Kwundaar says it's all right, it isn't a sin.
And you know where he's based?
Yeah. It's hardly a secret. His ships orbit the Union past the Oort cloud, just beyond the edge of the system.
Beep.
The drive's at maximum. We've left the Union of Traken now. We'll be there in less than an hour.
Alarm.
What the blazes?
There's a ship approaching. A big ship. It's matching course and speed.
Can't be. Pirates! We need to turn round, get back to the Union. They can't follow us back there.
Could it be Kwundaar's men?
Rumble.
Whoever they are, they're good at what they do. Is there any way we can get help?
Are either of you priests?
No.
Then just sit down and keep out of me way. They've attached a docking pod. They're going to
Explosion.
Good evening. I'm the Doctor. This is Shayla, and this is
Energy weapon. Kabe screams. Sound of something dry crumbling to the floor.
There was no need. I've come to see Kwundaar. Is that you?
[OC]: No, but I follow him.
Of course you do. I do rather need his help.
Anona opens her helmet.
He is expecting you.
He is?
Follow me.
Nyssa, there's no need to go. You're too ill.
I have to go. I have to protect the Doctor.
You can barely stand.
Nyssa cries out.
Nyssa! What's the matter? What can you see?
Kwundaar!
It's all right. You've got a fever.
The Doctor is in terrible danger.
We don't even know where he is. Come here. There you go.
The Doctor is going to die. I can feel it.
Hatch opens. Footsteps on metal.
It's a lovely ship you've got here. Bit militaristic for my taste, but I always admire good engineering. What do you say, Shayla?
It's crude, brutal.
Built to last, though. This ship is two or three thousand years old, isn't it? I doubt any of the crew are, though.
Kwundaar is immortal. Our whole lives of service a mere moment. He will endure for ever. Here.
Door opens.
You will go in there, Doctor, alone.
Here, like this? Not coming with me?
Door closes. Distant laughter.
Hello there. I can't seem to find the light switch.
Follow the sound of my voice, Doctor.
I take it you are Kwundaar.
Something slides back.
Ah, I see.
Welcome, Doctor.
Kwundaar, I presume.
You came here. You have business to discuss.
I do.
Nyssa, your companion, is dying. You would have me save her life.
Yes. You know about that?
(laughs) What would you do in return for her life?
You can save her?
Yes.
How?
Evil knows evil. I see all. What would you do in return for her life?
What would you have me do?
Kwundaar laughs.
I came here to save Nyssa. Time is pressing. She will die soon unless you help. I will do anything you want, if you can prevent that.
Will you?
We can discuss terms, but I always like to talk face to face with the people I deal with.
Do you indeed.
I'm not impressed by these theatrics.
Don't turn around.
I'm not frightened of you.
No. But you haven't turned around, have you?
That face of yours isn't going to scare me, so why not just show yourself, hmm?
As you wish.
The Doctor gasps then screams as Kwundaar laughs.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
DOCTOR: [OC]: Let me in! You have to help me. Please!
SHAYLA: All right, all right.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Hurry!
SHAYLA: What's so urgent? Oh. Sabian!
DOCTOR: This is Nyssa, my companion. She collapsed. Her temperature has fallen dramatically and it's still falling. I didn't know where else I could go.
SHAYLA: That's all right, you're here now. Help me get her inside. Sabian!
SABIAN: I'm here. Do you need help carrying her, sir?
DOCTOR: It's all right, I can manage. Do you know what's wrong?
SHAYLA: Not yet, no. Put her down there.
DOCTOR: Here?
SABIAN: I brought your bag.
SHAYLA: Good, good. This is my assistant, Sabian.
SABIAN: And you are?
DOCTOR: I'm the Doctor. Yes, I appreciate the irony. I'll answer all your questions, but Nyssa
SHAYLA: Has this happened before?
DOCTOR: Twice. Several weeks ago now. I induced deep sleep for forty eight hours and I thought I'd cured her, but
SHAYLA: You induced deep sleep? How?
DOCTOR: With a delta-wave augmenter. How else? Look, this may be important. She seemed fine after that, but recently she's shown evidence of psychic sensitivity that has left her weak.
SABIAN: She's been off-world?
DOCTOR: Yes, that's right.
SHAYLA: I see.
DOCTOR: She's going to be all right?
SABIAN: She's in a critical condition.
SHAYLA: The next hour will be crucial. You should wait outside.
DOCTOR: How is she?
SHAYLA: She's stabilised. She is still seriously ill. You brought her here just in time. We weren't properly introduced. I'm Shayla, although I think you already know that.
DOCTOR: I know you by reputation. I'm sorry to have imposed myself on you. Is Nyssa awake? Can I talk to her?
SHAYLA: No, not yet. While we wait for her to recover, perhaps you could answer a few questions.
DOCTOR: Ah. I am the Doctor, a traveller.
SHAYLA: But you're not Nyssa's father.
DOCTOR: Her father died. I pledged to look after her what seems like a lifetime ago now.
SHAYLA: I see.
DOCTOR: We travel together. Well, you know what they say. It broadens the mind.
SHAYLA: You have exposed her to danger, to evil.
DOCTOR: Despite my good intentions.
SHAYLA: Well, you know what they say about good intentions.
DOCTOR: Now look here. If Nyssa could, she'd tell you that she travels with me through choice.
SHAYLA: You've been awake all night, haven't you? You haven't eaten. Perhaps we could discuss this over breakfast?
DOCTOR: First I want to see Nyssa.
SHAYLA: As you wish.
NYSSA: Father?
DOCTOR: Nyssa, Nyssa, it's me. It's the Doctor. You collapsed again. I brought you here in the Tardis.
NYSSA: I don't remember that. Where are we?
DOCTOR: Where do you think we are?
NYSSA: That bird. It's a crested Avar. I think it's Traken. We're on Traken.
DOCTOR: Yes, that's right. Here, look. I brought your old clothes from the Tardis. They'll help you blend in.
NYSSA: But Traken was destroyed.
DOCTOR: Yes, but it hasn't been yet. Not for about three thousand years. It's probably best not to mention that to anyone, all the same.
NYSSA: Three thousand years?
DOCTOR: About that. I'm getting better at steering the Tardis, don't you think?
NYSSA: But
DOCTOR: It's time travel, Nyssa. If Tegan could cope with seeing her planet's past and future, I'm sure someone with your scientific training can.
NYSSA: Why did you bring me here?
DOCTOR: Where else could I find an expert on Trakenite biology? Shayla's one of the best.
NYSSA: What have you told her?
DOCTOR: That we're travellers. I kept it as vague as I can. You should do the same.
DOCTOR: Ah. This is Shayla's assistant. Er, Sabian, wasn't it?
SABIAN: That's right.
NYSSA: Sabian, you saved my life. Thank you.
SABIAN: Shayla saved your life, Lady Nyssa. Doctor, I think Nyssa needs to rest. And Shayla asked you to join her. She's obliged to report your presence to the Consulate.
DOCTOR: Yes, of course. Are you going to be all right?
NYSSA: I think so.
SABIAN: I could stay with you, if you want company?
NYSSA: Yes. Yes, I'd like that.
DOCTOR: Splendid. I'll pop in later to see how you're getting on.
JANNEUS: Consul Hyrca. (pronounced Her-sha.)
HYRCA: Consul Janneus, it is barely dawn. Why have you summoned me here?
JANNEUS: There was an arrival. Physician Shayla reports that a man brought a young woman to her during the night for medical treatment.
HYRCA: From outside the Union?
JANNEUS: There is some confusion. The woman is a daughter of Traken. It is unclear who the man is. One of us must commune with the Source, and the other must stand watch.
HYRCA: I shall stand watch.
JANNEUS: Agreed.
JANNEUS: I am ready. O Source that shines on all Traken, grant me, Janneus, loyal Consul of all the worlds of the Union, the illumination of thy perfect light.
SHAYLA: Foster, I have an appointment with the Consuls.
ETRAYK: You must wait to enter, Lady Shayla. The Consuls are in communion with the Source.
SHAYLA: We understand, Etrayk.
DOCTOR: Will they be long?
ETRAYK: The Source will take as long as it needs to, sir.
DOCTOR: Perhaps we should get back to Nyssa in the meantime. If her condition's as serious as you say, then every minute treating her could be critical.
SHAYLA: Sabian will keep her condition stable. We will wait here.
HYRCA: Janneus?
JANNEUS: I have seen much. There is danger, and a pattern that not even the Source can fully define. One that stretches across Space and Time.
HYRCA: What course of action does the Source advise?
JANNEUS: It was reluctant to say.
HYRCA: Reluctant?
JANNEUS: That's the best word for it. Consul Hyrca, I am convinced the Source is withholding information from us.
HYRCA: But that's
JANNEUS: Yes, Consul, I know it's impossible. (sighs) We must meet these off-worlders and use our own judgement. Has Shayla brought them here?
HYRCA: The man is outside. I shall summon him.
ETRAYK: Through here, please.
DOCTOR: Good morning, Consuls of Traken.
SHAYLA: Consuls, this is the Doctor. These are Consuls Janneus and Hyrca.
JANNEUS: Good morning.
HYRCA: Hello, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Two Consuls. I'll have to be on my best behaviour.
HYRCA: There are times when you are not?
DOCTOR: It's a figure of speech. I really must stop using them. You'll have to forgive me, I always find it difficult to relax somewhere so tranquil. In my experience, every paradise has its serpent somewhere.
HYRCA: Is your conscience really so troubled?
JANNEUS: Shayla, what is the condition of the Doctor's travelling companion?
DOCTOR: I've just been in to see Nyssa. She's a lot better, and
SHAYLA: She's critically ill.
JANNEUS: Will she survive?
SHAYLA: The darkness is upon her. I can't be sure that the light of the Source has reached her in time.
DOCTOR: I'm sorry, what exactly do you think is wrong with her?
SHAYLA: Exposure to evil, even the smallest amount, can corrode the soul. And that is what has happened to Nyssa.
DOCTOR: You make it sound like radiation, like a cancer.
SHAYLA: That is precisely the effect it has. The Source protects us, protects all in the Union, from evil's influence. But away from the light of the Source, the malign take hold. You're laughing, Doctor.
DOCTOR: It doesn't work like that.
SHAYLA: You don't think there is evil in this universe?
DOCTOR: Oh, I've travelled quite widely and met the most terrible people with the most appalling beliefs. I consider them evil, but I'm sure if you were to ask them, they'd tell you that I'm the monster, not them. Evil is relative.
SHAYLA: And this is what all outsiders think, is it?
DOCTOR: No, simply my opinion. I ought to warn you that I don't hold a Doctorate in Theology. At least, I don't think so. I may have picked up an honorary one somewhere or other. I lose track.
JANNEUS: Your philosophy is flawed.
DOCTOR: It is?
HYRCA: After all, Traken exists in the state of perfection.
DOCTOR: Ah.
JANNEUS: You don't think that Traken is perfect?
DOCTOR: The Union of Traken is one of the most beautiful and peaceful places I have ever visited. But perfection is something we should strive for, not something we can ever attain.
JANNEUS: And what faults do you find here, sir?
DOCTOR: Well, Traken has the death penalty, doesn't it? In extreme cases, you execute criminals.
HYRCA: To prevent the spread of evil. To protect all we hold dear. To maintain perfection.
DOCTOR: And your leaders are picked from within the elite, by members of the elite.
HYRCA: I understand that upon some planets you become the ruler by killing your opponents.
JANNEUS: Here the Source guides us. The Source is perpetual, infallible.
HYRCA: We bathe in its light, while the lesser races must skulk in the shadows.
DOCTOR: I was forgetting another figure of speech
HYRCA: Yes?
DOCTOR: Never discuss religion or politics at the dining table.
JANNEUS: No wonder you are jealous of us, Doctor. We have the incorruptible light of the Source. Other races have false gods, or worse, they have no gods at all. The whole universe envies us.
ANONA: (a young woman) Our course is steady, sir. All ship's systems fully operational and at maximum capacity.
ANONA: NARTHEx: As they have been every day for two and a half millennia.
ANONA: Vigilance is our sacred duty, Captain.
ANONA: NARTHExX: You're new, aren't you, Anona?
ANONA: That's right, sir. I was recruited on
ANONA: NARTHExX: I know who you are. I do check the backgrounds of my crew.
ANONA: Sir, I meant no disrespect.
NARTHEX: Ah.
ANONA: Kwundaar summons you, sir.
NARTHEX: Yes.
ANONA: It must be a supreme honour to stand face to face with the greatest leader. NARTHExX: There was a time when I thought like that.
ANONA: You mean to test my faith, of course, sir.
ANONA: NARTHExX: Yes. Yes, of course I do. Well, Anona, you may take your reward.
ANONA: Sir?
ANONA: NARTHEx: I'll allow you to go in my place, this once.
ANONA: (delighted) Sir!
ANONA: Hello?
ANONA: Is anyone there?
DOCTOR: Hello again, Nyssa. You're looking better.
NYSSA: Sabian has given me something for the headache. I feel so weak.
DOCTOR: Well, we're all doing our best. Quick, before the others come back, what can you tell me about the history of Traken at this time?
NYSSA: My people didn't study our past. After all, what could it teach us?
DOCTOR: It would come in rather useful now, don't you think?
NYSSA: All I Know is that you've brought us to the Primeval times, before the time of the Keepers, when the Source governed itself.
DOCTOR: Have you ever heard of Shayla?
NYSSA: No.
DOCTOR: The book I found in the Tardis library said she was the greatest authority Traken medicine ever knew.
NYSSA: By my time, all illness and disease had been eradicated. We had no need for medicine. Are you worried about her?
DOCTOR: Well, she seems to think you're possessed by evil spirits.
NYSSA: That's nonsense. One thing I do remember, people in the past were more superstitious. There was religion, so Traken wasn't a true paradise.
DOCTOR: All credit to her, you're responding to the treatment she's using. Although whatever it is that's wrong, I doubt it's the devil's work.
ANONA: I can't see.
KWUNDAAR: Follow my voice. Follow.
ANONA: My lord?
KWUNDAAR: Look at me.
ANONA: I'm sorry, I
KWUNDAAR: Speak to me. I can feel it. The Source, it burns.
ANONA: If we're too close to the Union, we could move the ship away. We could
KWUNDAAR: No, no, no. I want it to burn. I'll not hide from it. You, you're not Captain Narthex.
ANONA: No, sir. I am Lieutenant Anona. I recently graduated
KWUNDAAR: I know you. You have the reputation of being particularly devout.
ANONA: You're in my mind.
KWUNDAAR: Ah, you feel me there?
ANONA: Yes.
KWUNDAAR: Yet you don't resist.
ANONA: It is not my place to.
KWUNDAAR: Good. What were you before you joined my struggle?
ANONA: I worked ah!
KWUNDAAR: No! That was not before. You may remember a time before you were here. That time did not exist. It's a dream, elaboration.
ANONA: You are right, sir. Forgive me.
KWUNDAAR: You would not want to see my face.
ANONA: Sir, I am at your mercy. I will obey you without thought.
KWUNDAAR: (laughs) Yet as you mouth these words you still question me with your thoughts. That's my curse. I know that every follower has them. I know that every mind is devious, and every being that ever lived is a liar, a hypocrite, a cheat. I was betrayed, questioned.
ANONA: Sir, I will obey you. Whatever I might think, I will not speak treason, and wherever you lead, I will follow. I will not betray you.
KWUNDAAR: Yes, that is all I can ask of you. You're a good servant.
ANONA: I believe in you, sir, but I don't understand why you are here, on the edge of the Union of Traken. Any closer to the Source and it will destroy you. You aren't trapped here, so
KWUNDAAR: No, it is they who are trapped. The people of Traken, prisoners in their walled paradise.
ANONA: Yet, yet they are content to stay where they are. And you can never hope to destroy the Source. It's impossible.
KWUNDAAR: I have provided for this moment. Reached through Time and Space, found a vulnerable soul, exploited their weakness, and at my command, my agent will soon bring the walls of paradise down. Return to your duties. Prepare for that moment.
ANONA: Sir.
DOCTOR: Sabian, I'm looking for Shayla. Do you have any idea where she is?
SABIAN: Er, no, sorry, I don't.
DOCTOR: I see. You might be able to help. Could you tell me about the treatment Shayla's giving Nyssa? Whatever it is, it's helping.
SABIAN: A simple remedy for the fever. Beyond that, we are merely letting the Source do its work.
DOCTOR: The Source. Ah, yes. It's where you get all your energy from.
SABIAN: It is more than that. It is a sentient sun. The Source shines down on Traken and its people, while the rest of the universe has to live in the shadows.
DOCTOR: But you know it's a machine?
SABIAN: Of course. We built it, after all. Or our ancestors did.
DOCTOR: You don't worship it.
SABIAN: (laughs) Traken is a world of science, Doctor. We admire the Source for what it is, a perfect piece of engineering.
DOCTOR: But you don't ask the Source to provide for you.
SABIAN: Pray to it to grant wishes? No, Doctor. After all, what could we wish for that we don't already have here in abundance.
SHAYLA: Consuls, you sent for me.
JANNEUS: Shayla, the Doctor does not know you are here?
SHAYLA: I've instructed Sabian to keep him occupied.
HYRCA: You see, the off-worlder's presence alone is enough to make people break their word, to disrupt our way of life. I fear where this is leading.
SHAYLA: You would blame the Doctor for our hypocrisy?
JANNEUS: Show respect, Shayla.
HYRCA: You heard him say it yourself. The Doctor sees himself as a serpent in our paradise. He questions our authority. He questions the Source itself.
JANNEUS: What is your patient's condition?
SHAYLA: Nyssa shows little improvement. She's been exposed to terrible evils. She is suppressing anger, she has known fear. Her mental defences and barriers are almost non-existent.
HYRCA: Can you cure her?
SHAYLA: No. Given time, the Source may be able to.
JANNEUS: Time? How much time?
SHAYLA: Years, certainly. And I'm not sure she has the strength for more than a few days.
JANNEUS: Such evil inflicted on an innocent.
SHAYLA: I've talked to the girl. She's reluctant to give too many details, but she saw her father murdered, she's encountered soulless creatures, machine men and other abominations created to destroy all other forms of life.
HYRCA: The Doctor is completely irresponsible.
JANNEUS: It is deeper than that, Hyrca. His actions border on the abusive. It is a wonder Nyssa has not been murdered these monsters.
SHAYLA: From what I gather, one of the Doctor's travelling companions was killed in the course of their travels. Nyssa is convinced that the Doctor is a good man.
HYRCA: Ha! He's clearly conditioned her.
SHAYLA: I think he's a good man, Consul Hyrca.
HYRCA: On what evidence?
JANNEUS: He may very well be a good man compared with other outsiders, but that is not the standard by which we judge people, Shayla.
HYRCA: We should prosecute this Doctor, impound his travel machine.
SHAYLA: That is what the Source has ruled?
JANNEUS: The Source remains silent on this matter. My opinion is we ask the Doctor to leave the Union.
HYRCA: Nevertheless, we agree it is clear that the Doctor is dangerous. We must take every measure to prevent his malevolent influence spreading. If the Doctor leaves, and leaves swiftly, then I agree that may be for the best.
SHAYLA: And Nyssa? Without the Source and the medical resources here, she will die.
JANNEUS: Someone somewhere else will have the knowledge to save her.
SHAYLA: No, Consul, I don't think they will.
HYRCA: Our concern is for the entire Union. If Nyssa must die to preserve what we have, then so be it.
NARTHEX: Welcome back, Anona. So, was it the greatest honour of life?
ANONA: I'm sorry?
NARTHEX: Meeting our leader, the living god.
ANONA: He seemed sad.
ANONA: NARTHExX: Huh. Imagine being able to read minds. It's bad enough me knowing what I'm thinking half the time. I can't imagine what it would be like hearing other people's thoughts too. Did you try to see his face?
ANONA: He told me not to look.
ANONA: NARTHExX: But you aren't trying to picture it? You're not curious?
ANONA: Not about that.
ANONA: NARTHExX: You want to know why he's skulking here, when he could conquer the galaxy.
ANONA: You can
NARTHEX: Read your mind? (laughs) No, I can't, Lieutenant. We've all thought it. People are often drawn to what they can't have. Moths to flames, men to other men's wives.
ANONA: He's envious of us?
ANONA: NARTHExX: He can have everything he wants except the Source, and that is why he wants it. That's my theory, anyway. No one knows what he wants, or where he's from. No one's ever dared ask.
ANONA: He told me that we should prepare. That he would soon control the Source.
NARTHEX: How? The Source senses us. Just a little nearer and it will incinerate us, or turn us into statues. Oh yes, it sounds like a fairy story, but there's a fair few who've tried. If we cross that line, Lieutenant, we'll find out why none of them have ever come back.
ANONA: The Greatest Leader said he had an agent on Traken.
ANONA: NARTHExX: Then the Source already knows, and the Consuls will be moving in for the kill.
SHAYLA: Doctor?
DOCTOR: Ah, Shayla. I was wondering where you were.
SHAYLA: I met with the Consuls.
DOCTOR: And were Nyssa and I on the agenda?
SHAYLA: Yes.
DOCTOR: What was decided?
SHAYLA: I disagreed with them, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Ah. Bad news.
SHAYLA: The Consuls wish you to leave Traken. They feel you are a bad influence. You have until nightfall to leave, and you must pledge never to return to the Union.
DOCTOR: I see. And Nyssa?
SHAYLA: You must take her with you.
DOCTOR: Without treatment, she will die, and you're the only person who can save her life.
SHAYLA: Yes, I told them.
DOCTOR: So they're condemning an innocent girl to death.
SHAYLA: I disagreed with them, but they were unanimous. Evil must not be allowed to spread her.
DOCTOR: Nyssa is not evil. I am not evil. Shayla, things are not as simple as Traken philosophy seems to allow for. Wait, you said the Consuls are unanimous. I thought they relied on the Source for advice.
SHAYLA: The Source hasn't ruled on this matter.
DOCTOR: Why?
SHAYLA: They don't know. Doctor, the matter is settled.
DOCTOR: It most certainly isn't.
SABIAN: Shayla, come quickly. Nyssa is in relapse.
DOCTOR: Nyssa.
SHAYLA: Please, stay out of the way, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Of course.
SABIAN: Her temperature has fallen again.
SHAYLA: It's as though she's in shock. Nyssa, can you hear me?
SHAYLA: Breathe deep. Relax. Can you flex your legs? Loosen her collar, Sabian.
DOCTOR: Did you hear that?
SABIAN: She's stabilising. Yes, I think she's sleeping normally
SHAYLA: Her condition has regressed. Keep watch, Sabian. Doctor
DOCTOR: If you force me to take her away from here, she'll die.
SHAYLA: The decision has been made. The Source is infallible.
DOCTOR: But the Source didn't make the decision, remember?
SHAYLA: Yes, that might be it. We could lodge an appeal, insist we wait for the Source to speak on the matter. It would delay things for another day, at least.
DOCTOR: We need more than a day.
SHAYLA: Doctor, if we don't find a cure, then I don't think Nyssa will survive that long.
DOCTOR: Don't say that.
SHAYLA: I'm sorry, Doctor, it's true. I thought that I could keep her stable. I can't. I don't even know the nature of the illness, let alone its cure.
DOCTOR: Then why lodge the appeal?
SHAYLA: There might be another way. Kwundaar.
SABIAN: Consul, no!
DOCTOR: What is that, a drug?
SABIAN: His followers are fanatics! Murderers and degenerates.
DOCTOR: Not a local, then.
SHAYLA: No. He lives in the stars beyond the Union. But his followers worship him and say he's omniscient, that he grants them all that they desire.
DOCTOR: Sounds like a man to have in your corner.
SABIAN: He destroys all those who don't follow him. He stands for everything we on Traken abhor. He might satisfy the base desires of primitives, but
DOCTOR: But he's our only hope, so tell me where to find him and I'll take the Tardis and
SHAYLA: No, that's too obvious. The Consuls want you to leave, but Kwundaar is the greatest threat to our way of life. The Consuls will destroy your Tardis rather than let you have any contact with him.
DOCTOR: They should make up their minds.
SHAYLA: There is a way for you to go to him. Come with me. Sabian, if I'm missed, you are to say I have taken the Doctor to the northern shores for the day.
SABIAN: My lady, please don't do this.
DOCTOR: Traken has a spaceport?
SHAYLA: A small one. We still need to trade a few items with the rest of the universe.
DOCTOR: I didn't think we outsiders met your standards.
SHAYLA: Some are close enough for us to turn a blind eye, but they show their true colours if you show them enough money.
SHAYLA: Excuse me! Is this pad three? Do you know Captain Kabe? (pronounced Car-bay.)
KABE: I am he, madam. What can I do for you?
DOCTOR: I need passage out of the Union.
SHAYLA: We both do.
DOCTOR: I thought I was going alone?
SHAYLA: We need passage. I can pay.
DOCTOR: Ah.
KABE: Smuggle you out of the Union? Huh, that's a new one. It's usually the other way round.
DOCTOR: We have business to attend to outside. We're planning to return.
KABE: Are you now? And can I ask what this business is?
SHAYLA: No, you may not. Captain, I am a senior physician, and if I recommend that your permit to operate within the Union should be revoked on quarantine grounds
KABE: Then I'll take you to the courts, my lady. You think getting this permit was easy? I've passed all your checks.
DOCTOR: Captain, a friend of mine is going to die unless I get help. We'll have to leave immediately. Please name your price.
KABE: Not a terribly good bargaining strategy, sir, but, er, I'll take your money.
NYSSA: Have you been Shayla's assistant for long?
SABIAN: For two years. She's a genius, Nyssa. The finest physician Traken has ever known. The first week I was here, she saved the life of a man found drifting in space after an accident. He had been pronounced dead, but she saved him. And you are far from dead, so she will save you.
NYSSA: I feel weak.
SABIAN: Don't worry. The Source will sustain you.
NYSSA: I want the Doctor here. Where is he?
SABIAN: I don't know. He and Shayla left together a few hours ago.
NYSSA: Left? To go where?
SABIAN: The northern shores?
NYSSA: Sabian.
SABIAN: They've gone to the northern shores.
SABIAN: Consul Hyrca. This is a medical ward and
HYRCA: You are Nyssa.
NYSSA: Yes.
HYRCA: I, I see. Well, fetch me Shayla, please.
SABIAN: She isn't here. The northern shores.
HYRCA: Pardon?
NYSSA: She and the Doctor have gone to the northern shores.
HYRCA: She lodged an injunction against the Consulate with the courts. I want to know what she's playing at. Nyssa, you are ordered to attend a meeting with the Consuls immediately.
SABIAN: She's too weak to
HYRCA: Immediately!
ANONA: Sir, there's a merchant ship leaving the Union. It will cross the boundary in this sector.
ANONA: NARTHEx: It's not a scheduled flight?
ANONA: No. And it's not on a standard route.
NARTHEX: Kwundaar knows about this.
ANONA: It must be that agent he was talking about. Ah! Yes, I understand.
ANONA: NARTHExX: He's talking to you?
ANONA: Yes. We are to intercept the ship, bring the passengers to him unharmed. Do what we will with the ship and any of its crew.
NARTHEX: There should be rich pickings. Battlestations, everyone. Do you want this kill, Lieutenant?
ANONA: Yes, sir.
NARTHEX: Then suit up and get over to the launch bays.
KABE: So, business is good, and as long as I keep me nose clean
DOCTOR: And what do you know about Kwundaar?
KABE: Huh. His followers are incredibly loyal. Runs his operation like a religion. But the way he acts, he's more like a pirate if you ask me. His people do all right out of it. Share the
KABE: plunder.
SHAYLA: The wages of sin.
KABE: Oh, it's a good salary, my lady, and the way they see it, if Kwundaar says it's all right, it isn't a sin.
DOCTOR: And you know where he's based?
KABE: Yeah. It's hardly a secret. His ships orbit the Union past the Oort cloud, just beyond the edge of the system.
KABE: The drive's at maximum. We've left the Union of Traken now. We'll be there in less than an hour.
KABE: What the blazes?
DOCTOR: There's a ship approaching. A big ship. It's matching course and speed.
KABE: Can't be. Pirates! We need to turn round, get back to the Union. They can't follow us back there.
SHAYLA: Could it be Kwundaar's men?
DOCTOR: Whoever they are, they're good at what they do. Is there any way we can get help?
KABE: Are either of you priests?
DOCTOR: No.
KABE: Then just sit down and keep out of me way. They've attached a docking pod. They're going to
DOCTOR: Good evening. I'm the Doctor. This is Shayla, and this is
DOCTOR: There was no need. I've come to see Kwundaar. Is that you?
ANONA: [OC]: No, but I follow him.
DOCTOR: Of course you do. I do rather need his help.
ANONA: He is expecting you.
DOCTOR: He is?
ANONA: Follow me.
SABIAN: Nyssa, there's no need to go. You're too ill.
NYSSA: I have to go. I have to protect the Doctor.
SABIAN: You can barely stand.
SABIAN: Nyssa! What's the matter? What can you see?
NYSSA: Kwundaar!
SABIAN: It's all right. You've got a fever.
NYSSA: The Doctor is in terrible danger.
SABIAN: We don't even know where he is. Come here. There you go.
NYSSA: The Doctor is going to die. I can feel it.
DOCTOR: It's a lovely ship you've got here. Bit militaristic for my taste, but I always admire good engineering. What do you say, Shayla?
SHAYLA: It's crude, brutal.
DOCTOR: Built to last, though. This ship is two or three thousand years old, isn't it? I doubt any of the crew are, though.
ANONA: Kwundaar is immortal. Our whole lives of service a mere moment. He will endure for ever. Here.
ANONA: You will go in there, Doctor, alone.
DOCTOR: Here, like this? Not coming with me?
DOCTOR: Hello there. I can't seem to find the light switch.
KWUNDAAR: Follow the sound of my voice, Doctor.
DOCTOR: I take it you are Kwundaar.
DOCTOR: Ah, I see.
KWUNDAAR: Welcome, Doctor.
DOCTOR: Kwundaar, I presume.
KWUNDAAR: You came here. You have business to discuss.
DOCTOR: I do.
KWUNDAAR: Nyssa, your companion, is dying. You would have me save her life.
DOCTOR: Yes. You know about that?
KWUNDAAR: (laughs) What would you do in return for her life?
DOCTOR: You can save her?
KWUNDAAR: Yes.
DOCTOR: How?
KWUNDAAR: Evil knows evil. I see all. What would you do in return for her life?
DOCTOR: What would you have me do?
DOCTOR: I came here to save Nyssa. Time is pressing. She will die soon unless you help. I will do anything you want, if you can prevent that.
KWUNDAAR: Will you?
DOCTOR: We can discuss terms, but I always like to talk face to face with the people I deal with.
KWUNDAAR: Do you indeed.
DOCTOR: I'm not impressed by these theatrics.
KWUNDAAR: Don't turn around.
DOCTOR: I'm not frightened of you.
KWUNDAAR: No. But you haven't turned around, have you?
DOCTOR: That face of yours isn't going to scare me, so why not just show yourself, hmm?
KWUNDAAR: As you wish.

elements.text: [Part Two]
Distant scream.
What's happening?
That is not for us to know. Lord Kwundaar and the Doctor have matters to discuss.
That didn't sound like a discussion. Let me in!

NARTHEx: I really couldn't recommend going in there. Shayla? I'm Narthex, the commanding officer of this ship. Welcome aboard. I see no reason why your stay here shouldn't be comfortable. If there's anything you require?
You authorised the attack on an unarmed merchant ship. You sent this girl to kill its captain.
NARTHExX: I did. And now it's in cargo bay four having its hold emptied by my crew.
And you don't even feel guilt at your actions?
Lord Kwundaar commanded it.
And if Kwundaar commanded you to jump over a cliff you'd do it.
Without hesitation.
NARTHExX: I would too, ma'am. But I concede I might hesitate for a moment.
You are fools.
No. Kwundaar has provide all this, and he allows us to do whatever we please. All he asks is unquestioning loyalty.
And you don't feel any guilt for an innocent man's death? Or that the Doctor is being tortured in there?

Guilt? My lady, behind that door is a living god. I worship him, follow his commandments. He grants me all I ask for, intervenes on my behalf. Huh, there's not many that can say that about their god. And he has assured me I need feel no guilt if I do what I do in his name.
Why did the Doctor scream?
NARTHExX: The Doctor's looked him in the eye. Not something I've ever tried.
You've never seen his face?
He normally keeps it covered.
Then the Doctor is dead?
Well, the screaming's stopped.

O Source that shines on all Traken, grant we, your loyal Consuls of all the worlds of the Union, the illumination of thy perfect light, so we might ascertain the purpose of the Doctor, so we might protect the planets in our care.
You are Nyssa?
I am.
Consuls, as one of the peoples charged with Nyssa's care, I have to object. You can see for yourself that she is critically ill.
We could proceed without her.
Her testimony would be useful, but we could reach a judgement without it.
No.
You feel able to testify?
I know the Doctor. None of you here do.
Do you know where he is?
No.
The Doctor's Time Space machine is in Shayla's garden. The Fosters tell me it has
not moved an inch since you first arrived, so where is he?
Please, I've already told you, I don't know.
Consuls, I don't understand why the Source has not been consulted.
The Source is just a machine.
The Consuls gasp.

The Source is what binds us together. It is a machine, yes, but a hundred generations ago its activation marked the beginning of the Union, the banishing of the old ways, the dawn after the long darkness.
No, it enables this. It regulates the climate. It gives Traken unlimited energy. It stores and distributes information. But the power could equally well be used for evil, if we so choose. It is
To hear heresy from an off-worlder is bad enough. But from a citizen of Traken? Now, you have travelled widely with the Doctor.
Yes, that's right.
I don't understand why you would want to leave the Union.

I. It was not my choice, initially, but I have learned a lot from my travels. And I hope I have helped others solve at least some of their difficulties. Sabian, you help people. You understand, don't you?
I'm a physician because my father is, and has always wanted his son to be.
But you want to help me.
If he wasn't Shayla's apprentice, someone else would be, and they would treat you, and Sabian here would be a horticulturist or a chemist.
But you get satisfaction from your training.
I would leave it if I did not. But I would never leave the Union. I can't even imagine how it is possible to live out there.
It's been over an hour.
There's no need to wait here. I'm sure that when Lord Kwundaar has finished with the Doctor that he'll let us
Door opens.
We go in?
I suppose we have to.
Footsteps. The Doctor is panting.
He's alive.
His pulse is. Oh, I think he's got two pulses. They're both very fast.
Two hearts, eh? Does that mean it's more likely or less likely he'd have a heart attack, do you think?
We need to get him to your medical facilities.
(weak) I'll be all right.
You're awake.
Of course I am.
Here, let me help you up.
Effort.
You saw his face, didn't you?
I did.
NARTHExX: (laughs) He must think very highly of you.
Footsteps.
We're not allowed to look. Nor would we want to.
Door closes.
Very wise. I'm the Doctor.
I'm Captain Narthex, commander of this ship.
Could I trouble you for a seat and a glass of water?
Sabian, the Fosters watching Shayla's house have seen no sign of either her or the Doctor today.
They are by the northern shores, Consul Janneus.
What are they doing there? He's meant to be concerned about his ward, and Shayla is meant to be treating her.
It sounds to me like they have abandoned you. Perhaps Shayla has discovered the evil afflicting young Nyssa is contagious?
This is nonsense. Wouldn't she have warned Sabian? Wouldn't she have warned me?
Perhaps she wouldn't. If she felt the risk of remaining too great, she could flee without so much as packing a bag. Shayla is the expert on disease. Her absence speaks volumes.
Your reasoning is sound. But why take the Doctor with her? Surely, as the source of the disease
Some corruptions of the body have hosts that show no symptoms. They spread more effectively that way.
But Shayla would be affected herself, surely.
I do not pretend to be an expert, but I do have a solution. We remove the known carrier.
Remove?
Disintegrate. I fear we must disintegrate Nyssa for the sake of all Traken, and we must do so without delay.
No!
Sit down! The fact is that a cause of peril has been introduced to Traken and
A cause of peril? Consul, you sound like a superstitious savage. You should be ashamed of your, you, ah (rustle of clothes.)
Nyssa. Nyssa!
What did he do to you?
We negotiated. He's a particularly adept telepath. Unfortunately, as a Time Lord, I have rather good natural psychic defences.
NARTHExX: Unfortunately?
Yes. To get through them he had to push rather hard.
So he knows everything you do?
Kwundaar is omniscient already.
To all practical purposes. He can read minds. As far as I can tell, he can do it across Time and Space. Who knows what his limits are? He's more powerful than I thought, Shayla.
If he has all your knowledge, what can you offer him?

I have no idea. That's what we'll be discussing this afternoon, once I'm strong enough to go back. He holds all the cards. If I Knew what he was, where he came from, I might have some leverage. Captain Narthex?
NARTHExX: He's a god.
Yes, I see, but where does he come from?
Who knows that? Not me.
And if you did, you wouldn't tell me.
NARTHEx: If I knew, and I don't, it wouldn't make the slightest bit of difference. He's all-powerful, Doctor. You can't defeat God.

He may, just may, be omniscient, but if he really was omnipotent as well, well, he wouldn't be skulking around this ship, would he? Well, I have to play it the way he wants. Shayla, how long has Nyssa got?
She will survive the night, but beyond that
Who's Nyssa? Your daughter?
Nyssa is my travelling companion. She's fallen ill. Shayla thinks that only Kwundaar has the knowledge to cure her.
Kwundaar sees all.
He claims he does, yes. Now it's a matter of coming to terms, hopefully before he kills me.
NARTHExX: As the honoured guests of Kwundaar, you have the run of the ship until then. I'll assign Anona to see to your needs.
Thank you.
NARTHExX: Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to return to my duties.
Footsteps recede.
I don't trust them.
Kwundaar is telling the truth. Perhaps not the whole truth, but he convinced me he can cure Nyssa.
The people here are devious. They look at us when they think we can't see them. They hide things from each other. And they're pirates, murderers.
They don't have the same advantages that our backgrounds gave us.
You would excuse them?
I would help them, if they would let me free them from Kwundaar. But they don't see any other way to live.
Nyssa! Lady Nyssa!
(groans) Sabian, what's the matter?
I'm sorry, but you weren't moving. Your skin is so pale.
You thought I was dead.
(sotto) Yes.
She is recovered?
I told you, she is seriously ill. She must rest. You have to adjourn this inquiry.
Consul Janneus?
I see no harm in that. We shall reconvene first thing tomorrow morning. Sabian, you are charged with Nyssa's care.
Door opens, footsteps recede, door closes.
There's no hope for me, is there.
Don't say that, my lady. There is always hope.
You've done all you can for me, though.

Well, the spa. There's a warm spring not far from here. The waters are imbued with warmth from the Source. They have healing properties. They may not cure you, but will ease your pain. We shall go there.
And wait for the inevitable.
You look exhausted, Doctor.
The food here is marvellous, don't you think?
Yes. Almost up to Union standards.
I shall inform the chef.
How old are you, Anona?
Eighteen.
Same as Sabian.
Tell me, Anona. Why do you serve Kwundaar? Why do you choose to live this way?
He provides my body with wealth and my soul with meaning.
You must see that he is evil? He causes death and destruction. You see what just being in his presence has done to the Doctor.
Kwundaar teaches that to repress your feelings and desires is the only true evil.
On Traken we call that selfishness.
My parents died from Falconian plague.
I'm sorry to hear that, but I don't see how that is my fault.
You're both doctors. You know the cure.
I'm not a medical doctor, well, no, not really.
I've never come across a case of Falconian plague, but from memory, a small dose of Atolix can inoculate against it. A tincture of liquid Galas treats an existing case.
You have that knowledge, but you keep it to yourself. That is selfish. Had my parents served Kwundaar, he would have granted them the cure.
I can't help everyone. When I do, I wouldn't ask for anything in return.
So who was the last person from outside the Union who you did help?
Ladies, there's no need for raised voices. Anona, I try my best to help people, and the best way to do that is to teach them to help themselves.
Exactly as Kwundaar teaches.
Ah, no, that's not quite what I meant. Let a man sit by your fire and he's warm for the night. Show him how to start a fire, he'll be warm every night.
Set him on fire, he'll be warm for the rest of his life.
This isn't funny, Anona. You depend on Kwundaar. How would you survive without him?
Lord Kwundaar sees all, and will live until the end of Time. The question doesn't arise.
But there is another way. When my negotiations are concluded here, Shayla and I will be returning to the Union. You could come with us.
Stealing my crew, Doctor?
Her kind would not be welcome in the Union.
No, but there are places out there you couldn't dream of. I could tell you about
some of them.
I have all I want here.
How can you have?
The offer remains open, Anona.
We're happy where we are, Doctor.
As someone's servant? You can't really be happy.
Everyone here is here willingly. We serve
NARTHExX: I can answer for myself, Lieutenant. Working for Lord Kwundaar means I can provide for my family.
I didn't know you had children, Captain.
You never asked. Three daughters. They get everything I earn here. They live well, go to the best schools. Kwundaar watches over them for me, warns me if they might come to harm.
And do they know how you earn a living?
NARTHExX: No. No, they don't. But what they don't know won't harm them, and it does mean I have a very good reason to stay where I am.
It sounds like you're giving your children a good life.
You don't have a family, Doctor?
As a matter of fact
NARTHEx: I'm afraid, ladies and gentlemen, I have to break up this conversation. Lord Kwundaar has requested your presence, Doctor.
Ah. I'd hoped to delay a little longer. Well, wish me luck, everyone.
The water is warm, invigorating. Why don't you join me instead of standing over there with your arms crossed?
I am not the patient.
Your patient might faint again. And if I fainted in here, I might drown.
(tuts) I'd better join you. (water movement) You do feel better?
A little. How about you?
Me?
You've hardly slept since I arrived. Tending to me must be tiring work, and I can tell you are worried.
The water is very relaxing.
The design of this building is unusual.
I think it used to be a temple.
A temple?
You know, a place of worship?
I know what a temple is. I just didn't think there were any on Traken.
Oh, there aren't. Not any more. This place is very old, but this is a beautiful building. Well constructed, so they left it standing.
So what's the real explanation for the healing properties of the water?
The interface for the Source is housed in a vault under the Consul chamber.
Yes, I remember it.
But only the Consuls are allowed access to the chamber.
I mean, of course, that I remember where it is.
Ah. Well, the Source interface gives off heat, and that warms an underground
stream that runs beneath the chamber. That comes to the surface several miles downstream, here.
And as well as the heat, the Source imbues the water with beneficial properties.
Concentrating those benefits. You should drink the water, too. There's a fount in the changing room. But you already look a lot better. Your skin has some colour to it now.
You really aren't seeing me at my best.
I er, wish that I could.
But there's nothing you can do, is there.
Oh, my Lady Nyssa, if there was, then I would.
It's all right. I believe in the Doctor. I know he will do all he can to save me. And I know there's nothing you or I can do but wait now, so just stay with me, talk to me.
Hello? Kwundaar, my business here is urgent.
Door closes.
Watch.
A map of the galaxy, a star map.
What do you see?
Well, stars, being a star map.
(laughs) I see darkness. Darkness with tiny pinpricks of light.
You're one of those people whose glass is always half empty, aren't you, I can tell.
Now what do you see?
The Traken Union. It's a nice place. I take it you've never been?
Hmm. The Source would burn my flesh, annihilate me. It's a place that stifles such as me, but once, once I walked there in the cool of the evening.
You did? When was that? Kwundaar? There's a certain conformity there, certainly, but the people of Traken are free to leave and there's much there to admire.
You left Gallifrey to escape such a life.
There was a bit more to it than that, and whatever my reasons I wouldn't force anyone to do the same as me. The people of Traken have a good life. They are eminent scientists and artists.
They've had it easy. The Source provides security, gives them certainty. They don't realise it's a gilded cage.
You would destroy them for that, given the chance.
Yes.
Kwundaar, I hope you're not expecting me to destroy the Union for you. Not even Nyssa's life is worth that.
No. I see your mind. You have destroyed Traken already, in the future, in your past. And for that, I thank you.
That's hardly fair.
You allowed it to be destroyed.
I couldn't prevent it. Now, what do I have to do to save Nyssa?
You have seen the Source.
Yes. Not on this visit, a previous one. It's in the vault below the Consul chamber.
The Source itself is sealed behind a protective screen. Combination, two four five, six eight zero.
I really don't see the relevance of
If you've been in the chamber, then you know what I'm after.
Er, no.
Ah, you saw it.
I'm trying to remember.
Bring it to me. Hand it to me by dawn tomorrow and Nyssa will live. I have boosted her psychic defences. She will not die before then.
Look, you're going to have to remind me. Kwundaar, if I don't know what I'm supposed to do, then
Kwundaar is gone.
A clue would be nice.
There.
What are you doing?
Your captain has granted us run of the ship.
You will stand away from that computer terminal.
I am adding medical information to your system. Here, look. This is a small medical computer. I carry it wherever I go, and I've downloaded its contents to your computer.
What do you gain from that?
I'm helping you. Helping your people. None of them will die of the conditions that could be easily cured on Traken.
You're a fool!
I am?
Less of your enemies will die as a result of this, and you have gained nothing in return.
Door opens.
Doctor?
It's all right. He was much more civilised this time. Almost chummy.
You seem confused.
I am. I'll explain on the way back.
We're leaving?
Anona channels Kwundaar.
The woman stays here.
That wasn't part of the deal, Kwundaar.
I set the terms.
You do not need to hold a hostage to ensure my cooperation, Nyssa is that hostage, remember?
Shayla is not a hostage. She will never be returned. She is to be a plaything, a slave, until her death.
Doctor!
Kwundaar leaves Anona's mind.
You heard the Greatest Leader. Oh.
What's happening to her?
The strain of being Kwundaar's host is taking its toll. Come on, before she recovers.
(weak) Wait.
Birds singing.
You look a lot better. We could, er, sit together here in the, er, garden, perhaps.
Since we left the spa, I've not even had a headache. Sabian, that's odd. The Tardis has gone.
Consul Hyrca, what is going on?

Nyssa, by order of the Consulate of Traken, you are hereby placed in quarantine until your condition can be fully investigated. Then, the Consulate has authorised use of any necessary remedial action.
Including my disintegration?
If that proves necessary.
But she's no longer ill!
Yesterday Shayla said it would be years before you recovered.
I'm not sure how, but I'm a lot better.
You can see that for yourself.
How?
I don't think it was anything to do with what we did at the spring.
I don't see how to explain it, but ever since then I've not felt ill at all. I've not felt this good for weeks. Has the Doctor come back yet? Where's the Tardis?

We don't know where the Doctor is. His travel machine has been placed in quarantine until such time as it can be disposed of. And the order for your detention still stands, my lady. Apprentice Sabian, you are also to be closely monitored for signs of (pause) illness.
Consul, I have been in close contact with Nyssa for over a day and I haven't felt any symptoms.
(chuckles) The corruption of the spirit must be insidious indeed if you can't even feel it happening.
That logic is ridiculous. I demand to see the Doctor.
Foster Etrayk, take her inside. Neither she nor Sabian are to leave the house.
Yes, my lord.
Running. Alarms sounding.
Come on.
Where are we going?
Bay four. The merchant ship we came in is there.
Can you pilot it?
Oh, I'd have thought so. Come on, through here. Oops, perhaps we won't go that way.
Down here?
Why not.
Anona, come in. Respond. Lieutenant Anona? All units locate the Doctor.
[OC]: They were just here, sir. Level six.
NARTHExX: I need to know where they are, not where they were, soldier. Anona, how did they escape?
Anona channels Kwundaar.
They're heading for the merchant ship. You are not to kill them.
NARTHEx: All units converge on cargo bay four. Anona, get down there and coordinate them.
(normal) Sir.
[OC]: We have them.
Wait a moment, Anona. Where?
[OC]: Base of the merchant ship. They can't get the hatch to the boarding tube open.
(Kwundaar) The Doctor is to be taken alive. (normal) And the woman's life is mine. I'll get down there, Captain.
NARTHExX: They aren't going anywhere. That hatch is neutronically sealed. They need access to the command circuit to open it.
[OC]: We're less than twenty metres away, Captain.
Right, Doctor.
The boarding tunnel is through that door.
Hurry.
Neutronic lock. Simple enough to open. I'll just use my er. Oh, yes. I was forgetting. Oh well, have to do it the hard way. Let's see now. Bit out of practice.
[OC]: We're less than twenty metres away, Captain.
Hurry.
I'm doing my best, but there are fourteen trillion possible combinations. Give me a minute.
Hatch opens.
Oh, I impress myself.
Hopefully the ship wasn't too damaged when it was attacked.
A little late to worry about that now.
Hatch closes.
Thankfully they've not stripped the ship, just taken its cargo.
It's worth more intact. Now, let's see.
You need medical attention. You still haven't recovered from seeing
Two minutes, once we're clear. Shayla, you see that row of blue buttons? Press them all, would you? Top one first.
The launch bay door isn't open.
It's all right, I know. Now, let's see. No time for the computer to calculate the coordinates. Er, there.
But if the door isn't
Batteries to power, turbines to speed. Let's see. Er, pitch, roll, yaw. Ah, there we are. Gyre and gimble.
There are guards firing at us. There, on the monitor. They're in the docking tunnel. I think that girl Anona is one of them.

So she is. Now where's the er. Ah yes. (comms system) Attention guards, this is the Doctor. I'm terribly sorry I couldn't give you more notice, but the drive is on automatic countdown and will shortly be firing. You have er, eight seconds to clear the area.
They're retreating. You won't need to shut the engines down. You would have done though, wouldn't you? Doctor?
Here we go.
But the hatch is still sealed.
No need to open the hatch ourselves. It responds to the ship's drive being activated. Simple, really.
They aren't following.
Well, firing any sort of hyperdrive in a confined space isn't good for the local atmosphere. Next stop Traken. Full speed ahead!
And the course back is set?
Yes, locked into the navigation computers.
Then it's time for you to rest.
Report.
The Doctor and the woman have escaped, my Lord. They managed to damage our pad as they did. It will be four hours before repairs are complete.
My Lord Kwundaar, I throw myself on your infinite mercy. It was my error, and it almost lead to the Doctor's death.
My infinite mercy?
I have obeyed you. I have tried to serve you.
And you have, child.
My Lord?
I told you, I have an agent on Traken.
Yes, the girl. The Doctor's companion. I forget her name.
NARTHExX: Anarissa, wasn't it?
Nyssa.
NARTHExX: You're the reason she is ill. You infected her in the first place.

I reached out, searching for someone who might aid me. My requirements were precise. A native of Traken who was outside the Union. One who'd been exposed to evil. One with the skills or allies who would bring me what I need. Who could bring my restoration. I found Nyssa soon after she started travelling with the Doctor. I entered her mind, released her psychic potential. My power over her has grown steadily stronger.
She hears your words in her mind and her dreams, as I do. She's under your control, subject to your whims as I am.
Yes. You object, Captain Narthex. You imagine me doing the same to your daughters, violating their souls, forcing them to give themselves to me. I could do so. I will not.
NARTHExX: Your wisdom is unmatched, my Lord. You clearly understand the situation more fully than I do.
Nyssa sees the truth in your words, and, as I do, she is your good and willing servant.

No, she resists. She is a true Daughter of Traken. Her mind would rather destroy itself that yield to me. As I foresaw. And by resisting me, she will destroy herself, as all who resist me are destroyed.
NARTHExX: Then how can she be your agent?
She is not my agent.
But
The Doctor.
Yes.
NARTHExX: The Doctor is your agent?

He will do anything to save his companion. The Doctor thinks he has escaped me. He thinks he's outwitted one who sees and knows all. But he is mine. At dawn tomorrow he will hand me the Source, and Traken will be mine. And then I will have everything. The Doctor will see this and the Doctor will realise the totality of his failure. And then I will kill him.

SHAYLA: That didn't sound like a discussion. Let me in!
SHAYLA: NARTHEx: I really couldn't recommend going in there. Shayla? I'm Narthex, the commanding officer of this ship. Welcome aboard. I see no reason why your stay here shouldn't be comfortable. If there's anything you require?
SHAYLA: You authorised the attack on an unarmed merchant ship. You sent this girl to kill its captain.
SHAYLA: NARTHExX: I did. And now it's in cargo bay four having its hold emptied by my crew.
SHAYLA: And you don't even feel guilt at your actions?
ANONA: Lord Kwundaar commanded it.
SHAYLA: And if Kwundaar commanded you to jump over a cliff you'd do it.
ANONA: Without hesitation.
ANONA: NARTHExX: I would too, ma'am. But I concede I might hesitate for a moment.
SHAYLA: You are fools.
ANONA: No. Kwundaar has provide all this, and he allows us to do whatever we please. All he asks is unquestioning loyalty.

NARTHEX: Guilt? My lady, behind that door is a living god. I worship him, follow his commandments. He grants me all I ask for, intervenes on my behalf. Huh, there's not many that can say that about their god. And he has assured me I need feel no guilt if I do what I do in his name.

NYSSA: Please, I've already told you, I don't know.

NYSSA: The Source is just a machine.
